page.title: 20Local History
page.content: Little Billing has been a parish with its own church from at least Saxon times. In the Middle Ages the De-Longeville family were Lords of the Manor and remains of the 14th century Hall can still be seen. Later the estate passed to the Thursbys of Abington, a mile or two away, where Shakespeare's last descendant, Elizabeth Barnard had died in 1669. A fight between the Cavaliers and Roundheads took place during the Civil War on Billing Brdge - where the present mill stands.The Royalists were defeated. Opposite the Aquadrome is a circular earthwork which was probably used as a beacon hill for sending smoke signals to the Iron Age camp at Hunsbury Hill. There is a Viking tunnel under the road from the Priory to Little Billing church. In the 1940s German prisoners worked here.
